channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great CPAN modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report.
item.dc:subject: Weekly collections

item.title: The last word is my buddy
item.description: The post is educational, practical, and accessible. It effectively balances explanation with code, making it a good read for both Python and Perl enthusiasts.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: The Weekly Challenge #331
item.description: Solutions are clean, efficient, and concise. The regex trick for "Last Word" feels particularly Perl-ish, while the "Buddy Strings" implementation is methodical and comprehensive.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: Last word, buddy
item.description: The post is practical, well-structured and thoughtful. It balances clarity with technical depth, making it useful for readers who want both an understanding of the problem and insight into efficient approaches.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: You have the last word, Buddy…
item.description: It is a delightful blend of technical clarity, cross-language insight and personal flair. He delivers clean, idiomatic implementations for both tasks in Perl, Raku, Python and Elixir, all while keeping the tone conversational and informative.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 331
item.description: The post is highly creative, efficient and demonstrates deep Perl expertise. It’s particularly enjoyable for readers who appreciate Perl’s flexibility and powerful regex engine.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: String-ish
item.description: It delivers solid, language-appropriate solutions to both tasks across Raku, PostgreSQL and Python with thoughtful implementation choices and attention to clarity.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: The Last Buddy
item.description: A technically sharp and well-reasoned post. The first task is minimalist and clever, while the second task shows depth and creative use of PDL for character-level operations—succinct, performant, and idiomatic Perl.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge: Week 331
item.description: Both solutions demonstrate clean, idiomatic Perl/Raku style. The regex-based "Last Word" solution very neatly captures the core requirement in one line. Meanwhile, the "Buddy Strings" solution is methodical, explicit and covers all special cases.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: The Last Buddy
item.description: It is a concise and well-structured post showcasing elegant Raku solutions to two programming challenges. The writing emphasizes clarity and idiomatic use of the language, making the solutions both accessible and expressive.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 331
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Last Word" and "Buddy Strings" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 332
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "Binary Date" and "Odd Letters". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read the FAQ.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: Analysing FIT data with Perl: interactive data analysis
item.description: Printing statistics to the terminal or plotting data extracted from FIT files is all well and good. One problem is that the feedback loops are long. Sometimes questions are better answered by playing with the data directly. Enter the Perl Data Language.
item.dc:subject: Articles

item.title: ANN: Perl.Wiki V 1.29. jsTree version V 1.00. CPAN::MetaCurator V 1.00
item.dc:subject: Announcements

item.title: Proxmox Donates €10,000 to The Perl and Raku Foundation
item.description: TPF is looking for more similar-sized donations. See also the discussion.
item.dc:subject: Announcements

item.title: Announcing wxPerl 3.006
item.description:
Major change in 3.006 is a vast overhaul of most of the code to eliminate depending on wxWidgets 2.8 and 3.0 compatibility hacks. The code is much cleaner now, and builds without problems with 3.2, 3.3.0 and 3.3.1 (at this time latest wxWidgets release).

This makes wxPerl better prepared for the future! Future releases of wxWidgets should no longer impose substantial porting problems.

When building wxPerl, all tests should succeed. If you are missing features please issue a request on the issue tracker.

A good showcase is Wx::Demo, also available on GitHub. For best results, remove all installed Alien::wxWidgets packages and install the latest from GitHub.
item.dc:subject: Announcements

item.title: #731 - Looking for a Perl event organizer
item.description:
Hi there!

The Perl Mongers once had hundreds of active groups. Now there are only 22 listed and even them are probably not very active.

There are number of groups on Meetup mentioning Perl, however in reality many of those don't actually have Perl-related content or an inactive.

On the Perl Weekly site we have a number of groups listed and a calendar of events based on the event.json file in our repository. I wish more organizers used this calendar and the Perl Weekly to reach new audiences.

So here is an idea. We need someone who has time, energy, and interest organizing online Perl events. Each even could contain a presentation and then some free chat. The event(s) could be organized under various of these groups at times convenient for the local audience and the speaker. I have some presentations I could give and I am sure others could offer theirs. These presentation don't need to be the well-prepared and well-rehearsed ones you would give at a conference, it could be more akin to sharing your knowledge with some co-worker over a virtual tea. Contact me if you'd like to give it a try!

Enjoy your week!
item.dc:subject: Editorial
